# Ten pence (British coin)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Ten [pence](/wiki/Penny_sterling "Penny sterling") **United Kingdom**  
---

The [British](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") decimal **ten pence**
(**10p**) [coin](/wiki/Coin "Coin") – often pronounced _ten pee_ – is a unit
of currency equalling ten one-hundredths of a [pound
sterling](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling"). Its obverse has featured the
profile of [Queen Elizabeth II](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II "Queen Elizabeth II")
since the coin's introduction in 1968, replacing the [two shilling
coin](/wiki/Two_shilling_coin "Two shilling coin") in preparation for
[decimalisation](/wiki/Decimal_Day "Decimal Day") in 1971.[1] Four different
portraits of the Queen have been used on the coin, with the latest design by
[Jody Clark](/wiki/Jody_Clark "Jody Clark") being introduced in 2015. The
second and current reverse, featuring a segment of the [Royal
Shield](/wiki/Royal_coat_of_arms_of_the_United_Kingdom "Royal coat of arms of
the United Kingdom"), was introduced in 2008.

[Five pence](/wiki/Five_pence_\(British_coin\) "Five pence \(British coin\)")
and ten pence coins are [legal tender](/wiki/Legal_tender "Legal tender") only
up to the sum of £5; this means that it is permissible to refuse payment of
sums greater than this amount in 5p and 10p coins in order to settle a
[debt](/wiki/Debt "Debt").[2]

The ten pence coin was originally minted from cupro-nickel (75%
[Cu](/wiki/Copper "Copper"), 25% [Ni](/wiki/Nickel "Nickel")), but since 2012
it has been minted in nickel-plated steel due to the increasing price of
metal. From January 2013 the [Royal Mint](/wiki/Royal_Mint "Royal Mint") began
a programme to gradually remove the previous cupro-nickel coins from
circulation with replacement by the nickel-plated steel versions.[3]

As of March 2014 there were an estimated 1,631 million 10p coins in
circulation with an estimated face value of £163.080 million.[4]

Design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ten_pence_\(British_coin\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Design")]

###
Obverse[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ten_pence_\(British_coin\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Obverse")]

To date, four different [obverses](/wiki/Obverse "Obverse") have been used. In
all cases, the inscription until 2015 was ELIZABETH II
[D.G.REG.F.D.](/wiki/British_coinage#D.G.REG.F.D. "British coinage") 2013,[5]
where 2013 is replaced by the year of minting. In the original design both
sides of the coin are encircled by dots, a common feature on coins, known as
beading.

As with all new decimal currency, until 1984 the portrait of [Queen Elizabeth
II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") by [Arnold Machin](/wiki/Arnold_Machin
"Arnold Machin") appeared on the obverse,[6] in which the Queen wears the
['Girls of Great Britain and Ireland'
Tiara](/wiki/Girls_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland_Tiara "Girls of Great Britain
and Ireland Tiara").

Between 1985 and 1997 the portrait by [Raphael Maklouf](/wiki/Raphael_Maklouf
"Raphael Maklouf") was used,[6] in which the Queen wears the [George IV State
Diadem](/wiki/George_IV_State_Diadem "George IV State Diadem").

On 30th September 1992 a reduced size version of the 10 pence coin was
introduced. The older and larger version of the coin was withdrawn from
circulation on 30th June 1993. The design remained unchanged.

From 1998 to 2015 the portrait by [Ian Rank-Broadley](/wiki/Ian_Rank-Broadley
"Ian Rank-Broadley") was used,[6] again featuring the
[tiara](/wiki/Girls_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland_Tiara "Girls of Great Britain
and Ireland Tiara"), with a signature-mark IRB below the portrait.

As of June 2015, coins bearing the portrait by [Jody Clark](/wiki/Jody_Clark
"Jody Clark") have been seen in circulation.

###
Reverse[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ten_pence_\(British_coin\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Reverse")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/17/British_ten_pence_coin_1992_reverse.png/100px-
British_ten_pence_coin_1992_reverse.png)](/wiki/File:British_ten_pence_coin_1992_reverse.png)

[](/wiki/File:British_ten_pence_coin_1992_reverse.png "Enlarge")

Original reverse: 1968–2008

The original [reverse](/wiki/Obverse_and_reverse "Obverse and reverse") of the
coin, designed by [Christopher Ironside](/wiki/Christopher_Ironside
"Christopher Ironside"), and used from 1968 to 2008, is a crowned lion
(formally, _Part of the crest of England, a lion passant guardant royally
crowned_), with the numeral "10" below the lion, and either NEW PENCE
(1968–1981) or TEN PENCE (1982–2008) above the lion.

In August 2005 the [Royal Mint](/wiki/Royal_Mint "Royal Mint") launched a
[competition](/wiki/Coins_of_the_pound_sterling#Reverse_designs_\(from_2008\)
"Coins of the pound sterling") to find new reverse designs for all circulating
coins apart from the £2 coin.[7] The winner, announced in April 2008, was
[Matthew Dent](/wiki/Matthew_Dent_\(designer\) "Matthew Dent \(designer\)"),
whose designs were gradually introduced into the circulating British coinage
from mid-2008.[8] The designs for the 1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p and 50p coins
depict sections of the [Royal
Shield](/wiki/Royal_coat_of_arms_of_the_United_Kingdom "Royal coat of arms of
the United Kingdom") that form the whole shield when placed together. The
shield in its entirety is featured on the £1 coin. The 10p coin depicts the
first quarter of the shield, showing the lions passant from the Royal Banner
of England, with the words TEN PENCE above the shield design. The coin's
obverse remains largely unchanged, but the beading (the ring of dots around
the coin's circumference), which no longer features on the coin's reverse, has
also been removed from the obverse.

In March 2018, 26 new designs were released each for every letter of the
alphabet, representing the best of Britain.[9][10]

  * A – _[Angel of the North](/wiki/Angel_of_the_North "Angel of the North")_
  * B – _[James Bond](/wiki/James_Bond "James Bond")_
  * C – [Cricket](/wiki/Cricket "Cricket")
  * D – [Double-decker bus](/wiki/Double-decker_bus "Double-decker bus")
  * E – [English breakfast](/wiki/English_breakfast "English breakfast")
  * F – [Fish and chips](/wiki/Fish_and_chips "Fish and chips")
  * G – [Greenwich Mean Time](/wiki/Greenwich_Mean_Time "Greenwich Mean Time")
  * H – [House of Commons](/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom "House of Commons of the United Kingdom")
  * I – [Ice cream](/wiki/Ice_cream "Ice cream")
  * J – [Jubilee](/wiki/Jubilee "Jubilee")

  * M – [Mackintosh](/wiki/Mackintosh "Mackintosh")
  * N – [Nurses](/wiki/Nurse "Nurse")
  * O – [Oak](/wiki/Oak "Oak")
  * P – [Post box](/wiki/Post_box "Post box")
  * Q – [Queuing](/wiki/Queuing "Queuing")
  * R – [Robin](/wiki/European_robin "European robin")
